results.headline: How a Hero Hears the World

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Music Within

results.summary_short: A bad movie with a good heart, “Music Within” is a biography of Richard Pimentel (Ron Livingston), an activist for the handicapped.

results.headline: Loud, Proud and Busted: 3 Decades and No Regret

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Mr. Untouchable

results.summary_short: The flashy documentary “Mr. Untouchable” looks at the life of Nicky Barnes, once one of the most powerful drug dealers in Harlem.

results.headline: All the World’s a Soundstage for the Writer-Director-Star

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Slipstream

results.summary_short: “Slipstream” is Anthony Hopkins’s third film as a director and his first as a quasi-avant-garde filmmaker working well outside the mainstream.

results.headline: Hammering Out Songs of Freedom (and Nuance)
results.display_title: Pete Seeger: The Power of Song

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Pete Seeger: The Power of Song

results.summary_short: As the loving documentary, “Pete Seeger: The Power of Song,” makes clear, Pete Seeger is still busy, still angry, still hopeful, still singing.

results.headline: A Collision Course and Its Outcome

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Rails & Ties

results.summary_short: “Rails & Ties” is so self-consciously unadorned that it feels as if its director didn’t want us to think that she was trying to make a cinematic statement. She hasn’t.

results.headline: On the Road to Legacy With an Ex-President

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Jimmy Carter Man from Plains

results.summary_short: Jimmy Carter isn’t a real saint, but he plays one in “Jimmy Carter Man From Plains.”

results.headline: Repression and Oppression Collide

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Total Denial

results.summary_short: In “Total Denial,” Milena Kaneva’s incisive look at Myanmar, one thing is unmistakable: Its central figure, Ka Hsaw Wa, is the stuff heroes are made of.

results.headline: A Family Just Like Yours (if You Lived in a Movie)

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Dan in Real Life

results.summary_short: “Dan in Real Life” is neither wildly farcical nor mockingly cruel, but rather, for the most part, winningly gentle and observant.

results.headline: An Urban Fairy Tale

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Bella

results.summary_short: “Bella” is a movie that wears its bleeding heart on its sleeve and loves its characters to distraction.

results.headline: Chanel’s Visionary, Holding Forth From His Designer Throne

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Lagerfeld Confidential

results.summary_short: Those seeking career advice about how to become an emperor of fashion will find little if any useful information in “Lagerfeld Confidential.”

results.headline: Family Values Gone Awry in a Cavernous Mansion

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Living and the Dead

results.summary_short: A bizarre psychological study of degeneration and dependency, “The Living and the Dead” is a horror movie only in the most literal sense.

results.headline: This Is, Like, Spooky Stuff
results.display_title: Sarah Landon and the Paranormal Hour

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Sarah Landon and the Paranormal Hour

results.summary_short: “Sarah Landon and the Paranormal Hour” swan-dives into the tween-teenage market dominated by the behemoths Disney and Nickelodeon.

results.headline: Stumbling at the Goal Line

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Comebacks

results.summary_short: “The Comebacks” is one of those parody movies that presume that merely making reference to another film constitutes a joke.

results.headline: Life’s a Little Bit Worse Now That They’re Dead

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Wristcutters: A Love Story

results.summary_short: “Wristcutters: A Love Story” has an offbeat, absurdist charm that turns a potentially creepy conceit into an odd, touching adventure.

results.headline: Trapped by Circumstance

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of DarkBlueAlmostBlack

results.summary_short: If peace lies in acceptance, then no one told the filmmaker Daniel Sánchez Arévalo, whose first feature portrays repressed longing with been-there, done-that assurance.

results.headline: Human Frailty and Pain on Boston’s Mean Streets

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Gone Baby Gone

results.summary_short: With “Gone Baby Gone,” Ben Affleck has taken a satisfyingly tough look into conscience, to those dark places where some men also go astray.

results.headline: An Addict and a Widow With a Lot of Pain to Heal
results.display_title: Things We Lost in the Fire

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Things We Lost in the Fire

results.summary_short: “Things We Lost in the Fire” bends over backward to prove that serious American movies can hold their own with the best films from overseas.

results.headline: Seeing Red in the Darkness

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of 30 Days of Night

results.summary_short: “30 Days of Night” is a series of gory set pieces that seems to have been edited with a meat ax.

results.headline: Two Fathers, Facing Different Anguish

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Reservation Road

results.summary_short: The tears and the blame mix uneasily in “Reservation Road,” a grim, mechanistic thriller about death and suffering, life and healing among the civilized.

results.headline: When a Single Story Has a Thousand Sides

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Rendition

results.summary_short: “Rendition” tries to be thoughtful and respectful of complexity while at the same time honoring the imperatives of commercial entertainment.
